algorithm_technique: Use Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) to convert polynomials to point-value form, multiply point-wise, and then use inverse FFT to get the product polynomial coefficients.
problem_summary_simple: Multiply two polynomials represented by their coefficient arrays.
problem_summary_technical: Employ Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) to convert polynomial coefficients to point-value representation, perform element-wise multiplication, and then inverse FFT to obtain the product polynomial.
key_insights: Polynomial multiplication can be efficiently solved using the Convolution Theorem, which states that the DFT of a convolution is the product of the DFTs.
FFT is an algorithm to compute the Discrete Fourier Transform (DFT) in O(N log N) time, making polynomial multiplication much faster than the naive O(n*m) approach.
The size of the FFT array needs to be a power of 2 and at least n+m-1 to accommodate the product polynomial's degree.
